fr.sii.ogham.email.sendgrid.v4.builder.sendgrid

Class SendGridV4Builder

  • java.lang.Object
    • fr.sii.ogham.core.fluent.AbstractParent<EmailBuilder>
      • fr.sii.ogham.email.sendgrid.builder.AbstractSendGridBuilder<SendGridV4Builder,EmailBuilder>
        • fr.sii.ogham.email.sendgrid.v4.builder.sendgrid.SendGridV4Builder
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Builder<SendGridSender>, Parent<EmailBuilder>

    public class SendGridV4Builder
extends AbstractSendGridBuilder<SendGridV4Builder,EmailBuilder>
    Configures how SendGrid implementation will send Emails. This implementation uses SendGrid HTTP API.

    To send Email using SendGrid, you need to register this builder into a MessagingBuilder like this: 

     
 MessagingBuilder msgBuilder = ...
 msgBuilder.email()
    .sender(SendGridV4Builder.class)    // registers the builder and accesses to that builder for configuring it
    Once the builder is registered, sending email through SendGrid requires either an API key or a username/password pair. You can define it using: 
     
 msgBuilder.email()
    .sender(SendGridV4Builder.class)    // registers the builder and accesses to that builder for configuring it
       .apiKey("foo")
    Or you can also use property keys (using interpolation): 
     
 msgBuilder
 .environment()
    .properties()
       .set("custom.property.for.api-key", "foo")
       .and()
    .and()
 .email()
    .sender(SendGridV4Builder.class)    // registers the builder and accesses to that builder for configuring it
       .apiKey("${custom.property.for.api-key}")

    Finally, Ogham will transform general Email object into SendGrid.Email object. This transformation will fit almost all use cases but you may need to customize a part of the SendGrid message. Instead of doing again the same work Ogham does, this builder allows you to intercept the message to modify it just before sending it: 

     
 .sender(SendGridV4Builder.class)
    .intercept(new MyCustomInterceptor())
    See SendGridInterceptor for more information.
    Author:
    Aur√©lien Baudet

    • Method Detail

      • username

        @Deprecated
public SendGridV4Builder username(String username)
        Deprecated. SendGrid v4 doesn't use username/password anymore. You must use an AbstractSendGridBuilder.apiKey(String).
        Description copied from class: AbstractSendGridBuilder
        Set username for SendGrid HTTP API.

        WARNING: SendGrid v4 doesn't use username/password anymore. You must use an AbstractSendGridBuilder.apiKey(String).

        The value set using this method takes precedence over any property and default value configured using AbstractSendGridBuilder.username(). 

         .username("my-username")
 .username()
   .properties("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}")
   .defaultValue("default-username")
 
         .username("my-username")
 .username()
   .properties("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}")
   .defaultValue("default-username")
        In both cases, username("my-username") is used.

        If this method is called several times, only the last value is used.

        If null value is set, it is like not setting a value at all. The property/default value configuration is applied.

        Specified by:
        username in class AbstractSendGridBuilder<SendGridV4Builder,EmailBuilder>
        Parameters:
        username - the user name for SendGrid HTTP API
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • username

        @Deprecated
public ConfigurationValueBuilder<SendGridV4Builder,String> username()
        Deprecated. SendGrid v4 doesn't use username/password anymore. You must use an AbstractSendGridBuilder.apiKey(String).
        Description copied from class: AbstractSendGridBuilder
        Set username for SendGrid HTTP API.

        WARNING: SendGrid v4 doesn't use username/password anymore. You must use an AbstractSendGridBuilder.apiKey(String).

        This method is mainly used by Configurers to register some property keys and/or a default value. The aim is to let developer be able to externalize its configuration (using system properties, configuration file or anything else). If the developer doesn't configure any value for the registered properties, the default value is used (if set). 

         .username()
   .properties("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}")
   .defaultValue("default-username")

        Non-null value set using AbstractSendGridBuilder.username(String) takes precedence over property values and default value. 

         .username("my-username")
 .username()
   .properties("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}")
   .defaultValue("default-username")
        The value "my-username" is used regardless of the value of the properties and default value.

        See ConfigurationValueBuilder for more information.

        Specified by:
        username in class AbstractSendGridBuilder<SendGridV4Builder,EmailBuilder>
        Returns:
        the builder to configure property keys/default value

        Deprecated. SendGrid v4 doesn't use username/password anymore. You must use an AbstractSendGridBuilder.apiKey(String).
        Description copied from class: AbstractSendGridBuilder
        Set password for SendGrid HTTP API.

        WARNING: SendGrid v4 doesn't use username/password anymore. You must use an AbstractSendGridBuilder.apiKey(String).

        The value set using this method takes precedence over any property and default value configured using AbstractSendGridBuilder.password(). 

         .password("my-password")
 .password()
   .properties("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}")
   .defaultValue("default-password")
 
         .password("my-password")
 .password()
   .properties("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}")
   .defaultValue("default-password")
        In both cases, password("my-password") is used.

        If this method is called several times, only the last value is used.

        If null value is set, it is like not setting a value at all. The property/default value configuration is applied.

        Specified by:

        this instance for fluent chaining

The aim is to let developer be able to externalize its configuration (using system properties, configuration file or anything else). If the developer doesn't configure any value for the registered properties, the default value is used (if set).

   .defaultValue("default-password")

        Non-null value set using AbstractSendGridBuilder.password(String) takes precedence over property values and default value.

 .password()

      • unitTesting

        public SendGridV4Builder unitTesting(Boolean unitTesting)
        SendGrid allows to call API for unit tests. Set this to true if you are unit testing.

        The value set using this method takes precedence over any property and default value configured using unitTesting(). 

         .unitTesting(true)
 .unitTesting()
   .properties("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}")
   .defaultValue(false)
 
         .unitTesting(true)
 .unitTesting()
   .properties("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}")
   .defaultValue(false)
        In both cases, unitTesting(true) is used.

        If this method is called several times, only the last value is used.

        If null value is set, it is like not setting a value at all. The property/default value configuration is applied.

        Parameters:
        unitTesting - true to use SendGrid in unit testing mode
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • unitTesting

        public ConfigurationValueBuilder<SendGridV4Builder,Boolean> unitTesting()
        SendGrid allows to call API for unit tests. Set this to true if you are unit testing.

        This method is mainly used by Configurers to register some property keys and/or a default value. The aim is to let developer be able to externalize its configuration (using system properties, configuration file or anything else). If the developer doesn't configure any value for the registered properties, the default value is used (if set). 

         .unitTesting()
   .properties("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}")
   .defaultValue(false)

        Non-null value set using unitTesting(Boolean) takes precedence over property values and default value. 

         .unitTesting(true)
 .unitTesting()
   .properties("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}")
   .defaultValue(false)
        The value true is used regardless of the value of the properties and default value.

        See ConfigurationValueBuilder for more information.

        Returns:
        the builder to configure property keys/default value

      • clientHelper

        public SendGridV4Builder clientHelper(com.sendgrid.Client clientHelper)
        By default, SendGrid uses a Client instance as an helper to perform HTTP requests. You may want to use custom client configuration such as providing custom protocol and port: 
         .client(new CustomizableUrlClient(false, "http", 8080))
        NOTE: if you provide a custom Client, the unitTesting(Boolean) or httpClient(org.apache.http.impl.client.CloseableHttpClient) configurations are not used. You have to handle it manually.
        Parameters:
        clientHelper - the custom client used to call SendGrid HTTP API
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • client

        public SendGridV4Builder client(SendGridClient client)
        By default, calling SendGrid HTTP API is done through the default SendGrid implementation. If you want to use another client implementation (creating your custom HTTP API caller for example), you can implement the SendGridClient interface and provide it: 
         .client(new MyCustomHttpApiCaller())
        NOTE: if you provide your custom implementation, any defined properties and values using AbstractSendGridBuilder.apiKey(String), username(String) or password(String) won't be used at all. You then have to handle it by yourself.
        Parameters:
        client - the custom client used to call SendGrid HTTP API
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • httpClient

        public SendGridV4Builder httpClient(org.apache.http.impl.client.CloseableHttpClient httpClient)
        By default, calling SendGrid HTTP API is done through the default SendGrid implementation that uses default HttpClient (calling HttpClientBuilder.create().build()). If you want to use another HTTP client implementation, you can extend the CloseableHttpClient class and provide it: 
         .client(new MyCustomHttpClient())
        NOTE: if you provide your custom implementation, any defined properties and values using unitTesting(Boolean) won't be used at all. You then have to handle it by yourself.
        Overrides:
        httpClient in class AbstractSendGridBuilder<SendGridV4Builder,EmailBuilder>
        Parameters:
        httpClient - the custom implementation of HttpClient used to call SendGrid HTTP API. SendGrid requires a CloseableHttpClient.
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • intercept

        public SendGridV4Builder intercept(SendGridInterceptor interceptor)
        Ogham will transform general Email object into SendGrid.Email objects. This transformation will fit almost all use cases but you may need to customize a part of the SendGrid message. Instead of doing again the same work Ogham does, this builder allows you to intercept the message to modify it just before sending it: 
         .sender(SendGridV4Builder.class)
    .intercept(new MyCustomInterceptor())
        See SendGridInterceptor for more information.
        Parameters:
        interceptor - the custom interceptor used to modify SendGrid.Email
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining
